instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the related study to predict, correlate, and classify sensory descriptors of Cabernet-Sauvignon wines?
Output: Rate-all-that-apply (RATA), cluster analysis, excitation-emission matrix (EEM), partial least squares regression (PLS), and machine learning algorithms were used in the study to predict, correlate, and classify sensory descriptors of Cabernet-Sauvignon wines.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in predicting the panel scores?
Output:
The metric chosen in the study was spectrofluorometry, specifically the excitation-emission matrix (EEM) data obtained from fluorescence measurements. This metric was used in conjunction with chemometrics, specifically extreme gradient boosting discriminant analysis and partial least squares regression modelling.

The study found that the EEM data, when combined with the sensory descriptors obtained through the rate-all-that-apply sensory assessment, were able to accurately classify the wines into pre-defined sensory clusters with 100% accuracy. Additionally, the EEM data were able to predict the panel scores for perceived astringency with 68.1% accuracy.

Therefore, the chosen metric of spectrofluorometry, specifically the EEM data, showed promising results in predicting the panel scores for perceived astringency. However, it is important to note that further studies are needed to explore the relationship between sensory traits and fluorescence data in order to improve the accuracy of predicting wine sensory expression.

instruction: How were machine learning models utilized in the related study to predict, correlate, and classify sensory descriptors of Cabernet-Sauvignon wines?
Output: In this study, machine learning models, specifically extreme gradient boosting discriminant analysis, were utilized to predict, correlate, and classify sensory descriptors of Cabernet-Sauvignon wines. The models were trained using excitation-emission matrix (EEM) data obtained from fluorescence measurements of the wines. The EEM data, along with the sensory results, were used to classify the wines into pre-defined sensory clusters with 100% accuracy. Additionally, parallel factor analysis of the EEMs identified four main fluorophore components (catechins, phenolic aldehydes, anthocyanins, and resveratrol) which were associated with different sensory descriptors through multiple factor analysis. Partial least squares regression modeling was also performed to predict the panel scores for perceived astringency with 68.1% accuracy. These machine learning techniques allowed for the prediction, correlation, and classification of sensory descriptors based on the compositional factors of the wines.
